entry.title: Re: RAP navigation to object page of another app as a lin...
entry.content:
Hello @Shweta3005 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references.

Intent-Based Navigation, Deep Links to Apps, Deep Linking in Monitor Workflows App     

In summary, due to the clean-core principle in public cloud, the system does not permit you to create a header link in the Object Page by using CDS annotations. Simply saying, the public cloud does not allow modification of CDS UI annotations.

However, you can achieve that when you use UI Adaptation and then add a custom navigation link through Semantic Object. The Object page will open directly if your target app supports deep linking.

You may also find this source interesting: SAP Fiori Elements Tutorials, Courses, and Blogs

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Simplify Deployment and Monitoring with the CAP Console
entry.content:
As a developer, you've likely experienced the frustration of hunting through log files or wrestling with complex deployment procedures when you'd rather be focusing on writing code. The new CAP Console addresses these pain points.  Built by developers for developers, this tool evolved from the Developer Dashboard for Java. It simplifies both deployment and monitoring of your SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) applications on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), whether you‚Äôre working in Java or JavaScript.

This blog post will walk you through the key features of the CAP console, explaining how it streamlines deployment and monitoring, and why it‚Äôs a valuable addition to your development toolkit.

 

Getting Started with CAP Console

Setting up the CAP Console is straightforward. After downloading and installing it from SAP Tools, the console automatically scans your local processes to identify running CAP projects. Both JavaScript and Java projects are detected and listed on the start page, giving you immediate access to your active development work.

The console includes a "Remember Project" feature for projects you want to keep visible even when they're not running. You can also manually add projects, which is particularly useful for projects that aren't currently running or weren't detected automatically.

A filter option allows you to customize your project view, letting you filter by process status (running or stopped) and save status (detected or saved). This helps keep your workspace organized, especially when working with multiple projects simultaneously.

To utilize the full functionality of the CAP console, you need to install the CAP console plugin in your CAP project. The plugin is available for JavaScript and Java. Find detailed information how to install the CAP console plugin here.

 

Guided Deployment

Deployment is often a complex part of the development lifecycle, but the CAP Console makes it straightforward by offering step-by-step guidance. Starting a deployment is as simple as clicking "Add Deployment" for your chosen project. From there, the tool guides you through each step of the deployment procedure.

The process begins with the SAP BTP authentication, followed by SAP BTP account selection. The console presents a list of global accounts and subaccounts you can access, making it easy to choose your deployment target. If SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment isn't enabled in your selected subaccount, the tool helps you to enable it.

As a next step you have to select the Cloud Foundry space, where you want to deploy to. If this space is not existing, the tool creates it for you.

The wizard also reads your mta.yaml definition to identify required services and automatically checks resource availability in your accounts. In case of missing resources, you simply click ‚ÄúAssign Quota‚Äù and all necessary entitlements are added. In case an HDI container is defined in your mta.yaml file, the tool also checks whether the required SAP HANA Cloud instance exists. If it does not, the missing  service instance can be created.

You have two deployment options:

  • Deploy within the CAP Console: This option eliminates the need for CLI tool installations. Click "Deploy in CAP Console" and watch the deployment progress with real-time log information. The logs are automatically saved for later analysis.
  • Terminal Deployment: For developers, who prefer command-line control, the console provides automated Cloud Foundry CLI authentication and convenient copy buttons for copying deployment commands. You can paste these directly into your terminal without manual setup.

The console also supports default deployment target configuration, allowing you to set preferred global accounts, subaccounts, and spaces in your SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment that apply across all projects. These defaults can be overridden as needed during the deployment process.

 

Monitoring Made Simple

Once your application is deployed and you're logged into the Cloud Foundry environment, the monitoring view provides a graphical overview of your project‚Äôs structure and services based on your MTA configuration. Each component displays its current state through colored status indicators, along with real-time performance metrics including CPU and memory usage. Click any component to access detailed information about it, along with metadata like creation dates and direct links to the SAP BTP cockpit.

The interface includes practical controls for application management (start, stop, or restart your Cloud Foundry applications) without leaving the console. Where possible, you'll find direct links to corresponding sections in the SAP BTP cockpit. The console also provides information on the SAP BTP services defined in your project, such as the XSUAA service.

The integrated log viewer offers access to real-time logs with the ability to adjust log levels on the fly when using the CAP Console plugin. For Non-CAP applications and CAP applications without the plugin, Cloud Foundry logs are displayed instead. The log viewer includes convenient level switching ‚Äì simply select your desired level and view filtered logs without requiring restarts or additional configuration.

 

Easy Environment Switching

Most projects involve multiple environments like development, testing, production. The CAP console makes it easy to switch between them. This even includes your local development environment, though some features (like SAP BTP services) aren't available locally.

Environment configurations are git-friendly. They are stored in YAML files within the `.cds` folder, making them easy to share with your team. To remove an environment, simply delete its YAML file from the `.cds` folder.

Since the CAP Console doesn't store credentials, only team members with appropriate access to a space in the SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment can connect to configured environments, maintaining security without additional credential management overhead

Even if the CAP console plugin isn‚Äôt installed in a particular environment, you can still connect - though with limited features (such as viewing logs or accessing the UI).

 

Security Considerations

The CAP Console prioritizes security through the following mechanisms:

Rather than managing separate credentials, it leverages your existing SAP BTP and SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment permissions. This means you can only access resources you already have permission to use.

For deployed environments, the console establishes a secure SSH tunnel to the application. This is used to communicate via a WebSocket connection with the CAP console plugin for Java or JavaScript running in your application. The console minimizes risk by automatically closing tunnels when connections end or access is revoked.

On Apple macOS, encrypted credential storage using the OS keychain provides convenient access without repeated logins. This functionality can be disabled in settings if preferred, and it's not available on Microsoft Windows due to platform limitations.

 

Ready to Get Started?

The CAP Console is available for download from SAP Tools. Read the documentation and give it a try and see how much smoother your CAP development workflow can be! If you have any questions or want to share your experience with the CAP console, feel free to leave a comment.

Happy coding!

entry.title: Re: Unable to create contact in Fiori App Manage Customer...
entry.content:
@riteshinamdar : Sorry for delay but this is how we resolve our issue.

Solution was provided by SAP.

There were inconsistencies between tables.

Business Partner "XXXXX" has the value ‚ÄòYYYY' in the IND_SECTOR field in table BUTO00, but tis value is absent in table TB038A.

Further investigation revealed that this IND_SECTOR mismatch affects all Business Partners with Industry ‚ÄòZZZZ'.

entry.title: Credit Approval issues in SAP-ECC
entry.content:
we have a couple issues related to the credit approval process in SAP.

  1. Multiple Customer credit approvals are required for an order.  ‚Äì ie, when a customer delivery date is changed a new credit approval request is generated.  This occurs even if the $ value of the order has not changed. Multiple credit approvals on an order should only be required if the value of the order has changed as approval has already been granted.

entry.title: Re: SAP HANA PARAMETERS TUNING FOR PERFORMANCE OPTIMIZATION
entry.content:
Hello @Ashutosh_Pandey1 ,

thanks for this comprehensive collection and sharing this information. The topic is such complex (hyperscaler, hypervisor, OS, application release dependencies) that you can fill books - believe me because we did it. 

But allow me some remarks:

  • do not recommend any OS parameters as they change over time (e.g. THP from never to madivse)
  • changing the I/O scheduler are highly depending on the used components (e.g. for flash and NVMe system you should use "none" for RHEL systems / details)
  • you are not referring or mentioning tools like tuned profiles / saptune which are really helpful and supported by the OS vendors
  • do not recommend outdated software like HANA Studio
  • smart merges are something totally different compared to your description, please correct it or reframe it
  • is network no KPI in your opinion? keep in mind that there are also scale-out and HSR systems out there! The overhead between server client can also be important

Keep always in mind that your recommendation may adapted by others. Only recommend something for a specific scenario or within a versioning.

The are many good documentation out there via SAP notes (3311408) or other tools like saphana-checks (https://github.com/SAP/arp142-hana). Try to link them, because they are updated frequently. You can also mention other great articles which already present and cover similar topics like from @Laszlo_Thoma (Collected information belongs to the topics of query execution and optimization in SAP HANA database )

Keep up posting but don't use content which is dynamic and can be outdated one day later. Describe more the methodology and the useful notes and documentation with some examples.

Regards,

Jens

entry.title: Theming the Icon Control with the UI ThemeDesigner
entry.content:
Introduction

With the latest version of the UI Theme Designer, a brand-new Icon Preview page has been introduced, making it easier than ever to theme icon controls.
The Icon control is a fundamental UI element in SAPUI5 applications: it displays small, meaningful symbols that help users navigate the interface, understand actions, and identify the purpose of buttons, statuses, and interactive elements at a glance. Whether it‚Äôs a simple navigation arrow, a status indicator, or an action button icon, consistent theming ensures that these visual cues integrate smoothly with the overall application design.

The new preview page allows designers and developers to efficiently adjust and preview icon colors, states, and visual behaviors ‚Äî all within a single, streamlined environment.

Theming the Icon Control

To theme the Icon control, start by opening your custom theme in the UI Theme Designer. Once the theme is loaded, add the new Icon Preview page to your preview section. Navigate to SAPUI5 Control Previews and simply activate the checkbox ‚ÄúIcon‚Äù.

 

Select the checkbox ‚ÄúIcon‚Äù to add your preview page

After opening the preview, you‚Äôll get an overview of a wide range of icons ‚Äî neatly categorized by color, state, and type.
This makes it easy to understand how each icon behaves within different UI scenarios.

If you want to adjust the styling, switch to Expert Mode. Click on the tag icon and select the ‚ÄúIcon‚Äù tag.

 

Once selected, the theming parameters relevant for icons appear.

 

Inside the expert mode select the tag ‚ÄúIcon‚Äù to display all related parameters

The most important parameters for customizing icon appearance are:

  • sapContent_IconColor ‚Äì the default color of icons
  • sapContent_ContrastIconColor ‚Äì the alternative icon color used for improved contrast
  • sapContent_NonInteractiveIconColor ‚Äì the color used for non-interactive icons

With these parameters, you can now fine-tune the icon styling directly within the UI Theme Designer‚Äôs Expert Mode.
This gives you full control to match your icons perfectly to your application's look and feel.

What do you think?

How do you like the new theming options for icons?
Share your thoughts with us in the comments ‚Äî we‚Äôre looking forward to your feedback!

entry.title: Re: Bank statement parse error in SAP B1
entry.content: Hi , it would be good to know what is the exact error: The electronic file format can provide meaningful errors when the error pertains to any of the defined validations in the Electronic File Format, in the case of a BFP type, the validations are set in the specific nodes in the validation tab. You can get as well some information when the problem is in some specific information of the Target, because the target in BFP is an xml representing the internal structure of the bank statement in B1, so you may get errors that are typical of schema syntax. Other type of errors, as could be your case, could be more obscure as may affect for example to the Encoding of the characters on the file, or some problem in the syntax of functions defined in the Electronic Format. The best way to approach the cases is by doing advanced test using the Add-on Electronic File Manager. The process on how to do this test is described in KBA 3351973 - SAP Business One Guided Answer: SAP Business One - Electronic File/Document/Report Failed to be Added or Generated. Have a look at it.

entry.title: Re: Repair order planned costs double upon release status
entry.content:
Good day @rcirujano_us 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references.

Creating a Repair Order with a Service Product, Repair Order, Processing Planned Cost and Revenue, Calculation of Planned Cost and Revenue


Due to the public cloud‚Äôs clean-core approach, the doubling occurs when releasing a repair order item because the system recalculates you ongoing Planned Costs while also keeping your Baseline Planned Cost that was earlier created. If you have same values in both versions, the UI appears to show double costs, although the system does not post any duplication in CO/FI. 

I suggest you updated the baseline after release. Doing that will enable you avoid early baseline creation. Or you can consider hiding the baseline section through UI adaptation. See the links provided for further instructions.

To summarise, here is what you can do to eliminate the current state in your system:

  • Only make use of ongoing planned costs. Do not create a baseline until you finalise your planning.
  • You can recalculate your baseline by updating baseline and ensuring values align. It will eliminate doubling effect you are currently experiencing.
  • If you do not require you Baseline section for your business, use the UI adaption to block it.
  • Finally, check your system and ensure that you are not running any custom logic that is enhancing your cost calculation.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Using Tasks in SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager - Turning Initiatives in Executable Work
entry.content:
How Tasks Fit into SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager

For customers
Tasks represent the individual units of work that must be completed for an initiative to deliver value.
They break down large transformation programs into clear, manageable actions, each with:

  • defined ownership
  • expected outcome
  • start dates

This ensures transformation execution is not abstract but structured, accountable, and transparent.

For partners
Tasks provide the layer where partners can embed delivery frameworks, best practices, and implementation patterns.
Through the platform‚Äôs APIs, partners can:

  • push tasks from external project-management tools
  • standardize execution across multiple customer programs

This makes tasks the operational anchor for partner-led transformation services.

What a Task Represents

A task is a clear, bounded action required to advance an initiative.
Examples include:

  • preparing a process analysis workshop
  • configuring a system change
  • validating data for a KPI baseline
  • developing a proof-of-concept automation
  • updating documentation after process redesign
  • aligning stakeholders before rollout

In SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager, tasks ensure that execution is not a black box but a traceable, measurable workflow.

 How to Use Tasks Effectively

  1. Break down initiatives into logical segments
    Tasks should represent meaningful steps, not overly granular checklists or overly broad work packages.
  2. Assign clear ownership
    Each task must have a responsible person. SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager makes this visible across teams.
  3. Use tasks to monitor initiative health
    Incomplete or delayed tasks highlight bottlenecks early. The platform surfaces these issues in a portfolio view.
  4. Review completed tasks for value contribution
    Completion alone is not success. Validate whether the expected effect was achieved and update insights accordingly.

Common Problems SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager Helps Avoid

  • Tasks lost in email and spreadsheets
    Centralization prevents execution from becoming siloed or invisible.
  • Ambiguity around responsibility
    Assigned owners and clear metadata eliminate confusion.
  • Initiatives progressing without visibility
    Task-level reporting provides real-time status and transparency.
  • Repetitive work across teams
    Standardized task templates support repeatability and best practices.

 Why Tasks Matter

Tasks are where transformation actually happens. They convert plans and decisions into real progress.
SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager ensures that tasks are:

  • aligned with objectives
  • driven by insights
  • coordinated through initiatives
  • measurable and reviewable

This creates a closed-loop transformation cycle where strategy, evidence, and execution reinforce each other.

To work around this limitation, I attempted to create the variance at the model level instead. However, when I try to calculate the variance between Budget Version and Target Version at the model level, SAC does not return the expected values. It seems the model does not allow direct subtraction between different versions.

My goal is to have:

‚Ä¶while still being able to use Data Point Comments on the table.

Has anyone found a way to:

  • Enable Data Point Comments while using a variance column, or

Any guidance, best practices, or examples would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you!

SAP Analytics Cloud, connectivity

entry.title: task interleaving queue type, the same queue can be repeat in the same queue sequence
entry.content:
After different Queue-Type and Queuenames are defined, we assigned them to the queue sequence.

Some queues repeat themselves in the queue sequence. For example we have defined 5 queues.

The desired queue sequence is:

1, 2, 3, 1 ,2, 4, 5

In case there are many Warehouse Tasks in the queue #1 and #2 the system freezes on queue sequence #1 after the queue 3 is processed. The system doesn't go forward with queue #4 till all warehouse tasks from queue #1 and #2 are processed. When the queue 1 is processed SAP recognizes the queue type and assign the corresponding queue. SAP doesn't check the queue sequence number. We get an infinite loop for queue #1.

The navigation based on the last processed queue and SAP stores only this value in the DB (not the queue type position), thus if the queue type order has duplicates, the system only find the first occurrence and navigate based on it.

Now I have opened a customer influence request for that issue: Improvement Request Details - Customer Influence

Until SAP will solve this issue, maybe someone has an idea how this problem could be handle right now? How some queues can be repeat in the same queue sequence?

Maybe you have some workaround in your company?

Best Regards,

Justyna

entry.title: How to copy text from sales order to Purchase Requisition, Purchase Order and Inbound Delivery?
entry.content:
Ever wondered how to ensure that important text information from your sales documents flows seamlessly into your purchase documents? In this blog, we‚Äôll explore how to copy sales order text into a purchase requisition, purchase order, and subsequently into the inbound delivery. This ensures that critical notes, requirements, or instructions are carried forward across the transaction chain ‚Äî reducing errors and improving collaboration between sales and procurement teams.

Why Text Flow Matters:

  • Consistency: Keeps customer requirements visible throughout the process.
  • Efficiency: Avoids manual re-entry of notes, saving time.
  • Accuracy: Reduces risk of miscommunication between departments.
  • Compliance: Ensures contractual or regulatory text is not lost in transition.

How Text Flow Works: 

SAP text determination procedures define how text is copied between documents. The configuration involves:

  • Text Types: Define categories like ‚ÄúCustomer Notes,‚Äù ‚ÄúDelivery Instructions,‚Äù or ‚ÄúInternal Comments.‚Äù
  • Text Determination Procedure: Assigns rules for which text types should be copied from sales orders to purchase requisitions, purchase orders, and inbound deliveries.
  • Access Sequence: Determines the source of the text (e.g., sales order header, item level).
  • Control Settings: Decide whether text is copied automatically, editable, or mandatory.

Note: Copying of SO item text to PO item can be done using configuration. For copying of SO header text to PR or PO header text, you may need use enhancement IF_EX_ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST method.

Configuration Path:

SPRO ‚Üí SAP Customizing Implementation Guide ‚Üí Sales and Distribution ‚Üí Basic Functions ‚Üí Text Control ‚Üí Define Text Types‚Üí Sales Document Item

Copy and rename new sales order item text ID as required.

SPRO ‚Üí SAP Customizing Implementation Guide ‚Üí Materials Management ‚Üí Purchasing ‚Üí Purchase Requisition‚Üí Texts for Purchase Requisitions ‚Üí Define Copying Rules

Define Text type that would like to use link the sales order text.  

Define Copying rules for text linkage. Here the source object is Sales Order and Source text is the sales order item text that you would like to copy from sales order.

SPRO ‚Üí SAP Customizing Implementation Guide ‚Üí Materials Management ‚Üí Purchasing ‚Üí Purchase Order‚Üí Texts for Purchase Orders ‚Üí Define Copying Rules for Item Texts

Define Copying rules for text linkage similar to purchase requistion. Here the source object is purchase requistion and Source text is the purchase requisition item text that you would like to copy from purchase requisition. You may also define sales order as source object if you plan to copy direcly from sales order.

SPRO ‚Üí SAP Customizing Implementation Guide ‚Üí Logistics Execution ‚Üí Shipping ‚Üí Basic Shipping Functions‚Üí Text Control ‚Üí Define Text Types

Here you need to define text type, access sequence and assign the Text Determination procedure to the delivery Item Category. 

You can use existing header text ID or create a new header text ID as per the requirement. Assign the text ID to the determination procedure.

For copying PO header text to inbound delivery header text, create an access sequence and assign the Text object EKKO to the purchase order header text ID.

Assign the Text Determination procedure to the Inbound Delivery Type.

Similarly, for copying Purchase order item text to inbound delivery Item text, create or use an existing delivery item text. Assign the text ID to Text determination procedure. Create an access sequence and assign the purchase order text object EKPO and the purchase order text ID to the newly created access sequence. Assign the Text Determination procedure to the Inbound delivery Item Category.

Now it's ready for copying texts from sales order item ‚Üí purchase requisition ‚Üí  purchase order ‚Üí inbound delivery.

Conclusion: Text determination ensures critical information flows seamlessly across teams, improving collaboration and reducing errors. By configuring text determination procedure to copy texts from sales documents to purchase documents, organizations can guarantee that critical notes, requirements, and instructions remain visible across the entire supply chain transactions.

entry.title: Subscription Selling in SAP Sales Cloud V2 for New Deals using Guided Selling
entry.content:
Subscription Selling in SAP Sales Cloud V2

Guided Selling in SAP Sales Cloud V2 now supports Subscription Selling for Net New Deals. This blog will focus on the following processes to realize a new subscription deal:

  1. Creating a Subscription Opportunity in SAP Sales Cloud V2,
  2. Creating a follow-up quote in SAP CPQ, 
  3. Configuring products in SAP CPQ per the needs of the customer, and send updated configuration product details back to Guided Selling via Flush-N-Fill, and
  4. Reviewing opportunity in SAP Sales Cloud V2.

Creating a Subscription Opportunity in SAP Sales Cloud V2:

Prerequisites
  1. Configure the Document Types which will support Subscription Selling for Opportunities:
  2. Ensure Subscription Products are available in your system.
  3. Integration setup with SAP CPQ system.

Create a subscription selling opportunity using Guided Selling

  • Create a subscription opportunity using Guided Selling. Ensure you use the Document Type which is enabled for Subscriptions as maintained in Opportunity configuration mentioned above.
  • Add subscription product/s. Please note standard products can also be added to the same opportunity.
  • Additional fields available in the Product table for subscription products are:
    • Total Contract Value which is the Net Amount field.
    • Contract Start and End Dates which are Revenue Start and End dates
    • Billing Cycle is uploaded from S/4 HANA and is available in Product Master
    • Contract Duration is a free form date field and controls the Start and End dates of Subscription
    • ACV (Annualized Contract Value) is a calculated field based on Net Amount and Start and End Dates

Create a follow-up quote in SAP CPQ

  • Create a follow-up Sales Quote in SAP CPQ system by selecting the appropriate action
  • On the intermediate screen that comes up you can select/deselect the products you want to send for quote creation. 
  • Note: Sales Quote can also be created without sending any products to SAP CPQ.

Configure products in SAP CPQ and send updates back to Opportunity via Flush-N-Fill

  • Configure products in SAP CPQ system. Configurable products may have sub-items and get added to the sales quote in SAP CPQ system. Upon saving this information is sent back to the Opportunity where all the product items are updated based on information coming from SAP CPQ. 
  • Flush-N-Fill: Once Sales Quote is saved in SAP CPQ, the product table items in opportunity are over-written by information coming from Sales Quote. The following rules apply for this process:
    • If the item already exists in opportunity then this is updated,
    • new items in Sales Quote are added to the Opportunity, and
    • Items not sent to SAP CPQ will be removed from the Opportunity. 

Review Opportunity

  • Review the opportunity.
  • Products that have sub-items are brought into the opportunity. (Please note, these products must already exist in SAP Sales Cloud V2 to avoid errors during the Flush-N-Fill process).
  • Expected Value of the Opportunity is updated from Sales Quotes. ACV values are header are also calculated with the latest information.
  • Product table values are also updated from Sales Quote

The Net New Deal Subscription Opportunity is now ready. Link to the Sales Quote is also available in the Opportunity's Sales Quote section. Clicking on the link launches SAP CPQ quote in a new browser window. 

I hope this blog has been useful to get you started with Subscription Selling in SAP Sales Cloud V2.

Regards,

Shailesh Mane

entry.title: The 2025 SAP Logistics Private Cloud Advent Calendar
entry.content:
We have reached the closing month of 2025, and that means that the winter holiday season is upon us. So, in order to lighten the mood and lift up some spirits, we at the SAP Logistics private cloud Product Management team want to continue the timeless tradition of the virtual Advent calendar blog post.  
For those not familiar with the calendar, it is a Christmas tradition originating in Germany, which counts down the days until Christmas beginning with December 1st. Normally, these calendars contain sweets or other small gifts and trinkets, which are hidden behind the calendar doors representing a day. As this is a virtual calendar, we will be sharing daily various highlight content that either flew under the radar during initial publishing or we did not manage to share during the year.

We will be updating this article with a new paragraph each day up until December 24th, so you can bookmark this page until then for easier access to the daily updates.
We hope you enjoy this article and that the information you will discover proves useful and exciting.

DAY 1: SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Extended Warehouse Management Private Edition 2023 FPS03 ‚Äì What‚Äôs New

And to start off, let‚Äôs revisit our first article of the year, which covers the updates delivered with the SAP S/4HANA 2023 Feature Pack 3 release. This release further sharpened our Advanced Shipping & Receiving integration and built on the capabilities that were added in the SAP S/4HANA 2023 Feature Pack 2. We‚Äôve also introduced a new machine‚Äëlearning feature called Predictive Labor Demand Planning that helps warehouse shift managers plan daily tasks more accurately and efficiently by using historical workload records to calculate a planned duration for warehouse workload records and then use those records to plan outbound delivery orders. 

Aside from this, other highlights we delivered with this release include:

  • Introducing a new integration of decentralized Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) and Transportation Management (TM) with SAP Global Trade Services (GTS) which supports the execution of the outbound (or export) process.
  • Enabling users to search for waves, wave items, and wave-relevant warehouse requests that are part of Advanced Shipping and Receiving deliveries in the Maintain Waves app (transaction /SCWM/WAVE) and the warehouse monitor (transaction /SCWM/MON).
  • Providing users the ability to enter a text of up to 50 characters for goods issues and cancellations in several apps, for example, to add an explanation or other information to the goods movement.

To see more details on the above mentioned topics as well as see what other enhancements we delivered with this release, I highly encourage you to explore our latest ‚ÄúSAP EWM in SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03 ‚Äì What‚Äôs New‚Äù slide deck.

You can also find more technical details and documentation on the above listed topic and others we left out via the ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs New‚Äù viewer on the Help Documentation portal.

entry.title: The 'Version 1.0' Mindset that keeps me, my mentees, and the BTP teams Upskilling
entry.content:
In my previous blog, I wrote about why people come before process and technology in the SAP BTP journey, or any other transformation project. Once you accept that truth, the next challenge appears almost immediately: how to keep people and their skills up to date, and how to motivate them to stay up to date? In this fast-paced world, technology is constantly evolving. Look at TechEd announcements - SAP RPT-1, SAP BDC connect, AI Agents and MCP servers... the list goes on and on... What do we do? The learning goal is a moving target; you come to a point, and then the goal changes... this is the new normal. And let's be honest, motivation in these situations becomes the biggest hurdle. Everyone knows upskilling is important. Everyone agrees BTP is evolving fast. But finding energy to stay updated? That's where reality hits! And this is where I want to share something personal....

How do I Keep Myself Motivated?

Just like we expect the team to be in a continuous learning mode, we need to hold ourselves accountable, too. And the way I do that is slightly unusual, but effective (at least as of now).

Now and then, I look in the mirror and remind myself:

"Mirror mirror on the wall, I'm still version 1.0 after all."

It's my version of saying I'm not the finished version of myself yet. I'm not the expert; there is always more to learn, more to explore and more gaps to fill. And ultimately, it's a reminder to stay humble, stay hungry and not get too comfortable with what I already know.

This idea is not new; it comes from someone who inspired me a lot while I was working with HCL Tech - Vineet Nayar, former CEO of HCL Technologies. In his book 'Employees First, Customers Second', he talks about the transformation phase he led at HCL Tech. The phase was called 'Mirror, Mirror: Confronting the Truth'. He encouraged the teams to be brutally honest about where they stood, so they could clearly see where they needed to go.

Employees First, Customers Second by Vineet Nayar

So, when I talk about upskilling the team, or the mentees, I start with myself. I have my mirror moments as well, and I need to fill those gaps. Just like I do individually, a few of my mentees are also following the same trick, and they say it works. I believe teams also need their own mirror moment. A space where they can openly acknowledge: We don't know this yet, we are not confident about this service....

There is no shame in that. It's the healthy sign of a learning culture. The only difference I see from individually practising the trick to the teams is the goals, the moving targets. Individuals target as per their choice, needs, and their vision of their own future self, while teams can follow a collaborative approach where we fill the gaps in the team, rather than filling gaps individually. Let's be honest, one person cannot do it all! Team members need to complement each other.

But philosophy is good, what about practicality?

We always want things to happen, and we work towards them. Here is what I propose for teams, from an experience I have gained by practising myself and what I have heard from my mentees:

1. Start by defining the current state and the moving goal.

The mirror exercise - who are you today, what do you want to achieve? But this is an individual version. As a team, what we want to achieve should be the focus.

2. Identify team members and work towards upskilling in a way that complements the team. How do we do that?

One team member cannot be solely responsible for R&D; it should be a shared responsibility. That's how you complement the team.

3. Plan your learning.

Block calendars for learning. There is no alternative. Work will keep you busy every time. Take out time, upskill. Daily/Weekly micro-learning helps initially, and then ramps up based on interest and the subject

4. Frequent check-ins

Keep doing mirror exercise frequently to evaluate what you have or the team has achieved and what is left. Frequency could be monthly if you are on a weekly micro-learning plan, or weekly if on a daily micro-learning plan.

5. Share out as a team

Build PoCs, share with the wider team. This gives you visibility, builds confidence, and motivates others, ultimately helping organisations in the long run.

Do not chase perfection, chase progress. There is one lesson I have learnt in this fast-changing tech stack is nobody knows everything, but everyone can learn something every week/day. Small steps beat big, unrealistic goals. Small wins beat grand transformations. Small continuous upgrades beat occasional 'reactive learning'.

All this starts with the mirror, individually and collectively.

Your Mirror Moment?

What's one skill gap you've been avoiding? What's one thing you're 'version 1.0' on? Share this with your team - not as a confession, but as an invitation, so they feel comfortable sharing their 'version 1.0s'. Please feel free to share how you/your team are coping with the tech stack change and how you are upskilling.

entry.title: Re: -gb high - a good idea for dedicated servers?
entry.content: The GB high setting does not give any clear real-world boost on dedicated SQLA Windows servers. Most setups run fine on defaults, and unless you are pushing the CPU hard, you won't notice much difference. SQLA's general rule holds try here that, avoid changing core settings without a proven need. This flag is not a magic performance switch.

entry.title: Maximising AI Potential: A Blueprint for Business Success
entry.content:
Introduction

In an era defined by rapid technological advancement, businesses face both significant challenges and valuable opportunities as they pursue digital transformation and integrate AI-driven solutions. As organisations work to maintain a competitive edge, AI‚Äôs impact on business strategy, customer experience, and operational efficiency has become increasingly pivotal.

As part of my recent doctoral studies in Digitalisation, specialising in Technology Adoption and AI Integration at IAE Nice, Graduate School of Management, Universit√© C√¥te d‚ÄôAzur, I explored this evolving landscape in depth through research focused on SAP customers. I am Happy to share the key findings through a series of insightful and practical articles, each offering guidance for both SAP customer leadership and SAP executives navigating the complexities of AI adoption and technology transformation.

  1. Maximising AI Potential: A Blueprint for Business Success (THIS ARTICLE)
  2. Roadblocks to AI Adoption
  3. Is SAP Business Data Cloud the Answer to Your AI Ambitions?

In an era marked by rapid technological advancements, businesses face the dual challenge and opportunity of integrating AI-driven solutions. As organisations strive for competitive advantage, the role of AI in transforming business strategies, enhancing customer experiences, and driving operational efficiency cannot be overstated. This blog explores effective strategies for helping customers navigate the fast-changing AI world, drawing insights from my doctorate reproach aiming to develop a robust theoretical model and managerial blueprint for executive technology transformation and change management.

The Role of AI in Business

Over recent decades, AI has revolutionised how businesses operate, driving personalised marketing, strategic planning, and data-driven insights. Companies now rely on AI-driven chatbots for customer interaction, automated processes for operational efficiency, and data analytics for strategic decisions. The increasing digitization leads to the generation of vast amounts of data, making advanced digital technology indispensable for extracting value from this data. However, this shift also presents challenges, as many businesses struggle to adopt new technologies swiftly enough to remain competitive. Furthermore, technology vendors face the challenge of marketing their innovative solutions effectively and bridging the gap between innovation and adoption.

Key Factors for Successful AI Adoption

Key findings highlight the importance of strategic alignment, collaborative change management, cost considerations, customer experience, and vendor support in the successful adoption of AI technologies. Businesses must ensure AI solutions are in line with their strategic goals to add value and sustainability. Handling change effectively is crucial, involving stakeholders early and prioritising leadership support to cultivate an innovative culture. Financial implications are essential in decision-making, making it vital for organisations to perform detailed cost-benefit analyses to assure profitable returns on AI investments. Enhancing customer experience through AI-driven solutions with user-friendly and personalised interfaces can significantly boost business success. Finally, robust vendor support and training are necessary to facilitate a smooth transition and maximise the advantages of AI technologies, aligning with organisational needs and challenges.

Bridging the Gap: The Fast-Track Model

The Robust Technology Adoption and Contract Retention Model (Fast-Track) is a theoretical framework developed as part of my doctoral studies to provide insights into the multifaceted aspects of technology adoption and retention from both technology vendors' and users' perspectives. The model emphasises understanding and addressing barriers and enablers in three key categories: organisational, personal, and external.

Drawing on established theories like the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM), Diffusion of Innovations Theory, Task-Technology Fit, and the Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology (UTAUT), the model examines how organisational vision, planning, and stakeholder management influence successful technology adoption. Additionally, it considers strategic management theories such as Kaplan & Norton's Balanced Scorecard framework, which aligns technology strategies with business objectives. The Fast-Track model comprises two primary lifecycle outlines: the Technology Utilisation Lifecycle (for customers) and the Technology Deployment Lifecycle (for SAP/vendors). The former progresses through strategic vision setting, planning, implementation, continuous improvement, and renewal, ensuring technology aligns with evolving business needs. The latter involves market research, sales, implementation, and continuous support, highlighting the importance of understanding customer needs and maintaining engagement.

Furthermore, the model highlights the significance of external factors like industry standards, adoption costs, and vendor support in shaping technology deployment strategies. By addressing these factors, both vendors and users can enhance satisfaction, competitive advantage, and the lifecycle value of technology. Personal attitudes, user training, and change management are additional aspects considered vital in mitigating resistance and enhancing technology adoption. Integrating concepts from technology acceptance models, the framework details how perceived usefulness, ease of use, and associated personal and organisational barriers impact technology uptake and retention. In essence, the Fast-Track model provides a comprehensive strategic pathway for navigating technology adoption and contract retention complexities. It encourages continuous engagement, adaptation, and alignment of technology with organisational goals, thus facilitating successful integration and sustained competitive advantage.

 

Key Findings and Analyses:

My doctorate research delves into the multifaceted dynamics of technology adoption and contract retention among SAP and various user industries by studying 29 SAP Customers and their Partners across diverse sectors. Utilizing Lexical analysis with NVivo software, the research categorizes and quantifies essential terms, phrases, and themes from interview transcripts, providing a structured and numerical understanding of the content with an emphasis on explicit aspects such as words and visual elements. Key findings include the pivotal role of technology perception in adoption, where strategic alignment with company goals and operational enhancement is crucial, influenced by both internal and external factors like market competition and regulatory requirements. Effective technology adoption requires strategic planning, cost management, and user acceptance, while organizational and personal barriers such as resistance to change and fear of job loss need addressing through robust change management and leadership support. Externally, factors like industry norms and regulatory compliance shape adoption strategies. The cost of technology emerges as a critical determinant, with companies needing to consider both direct and ancillary expenses versus strategic benefits. Positive end-user experiences significantly influence IT contract renewals, with organizations valuing user satisfaction highly. Evaluating alternative vendors involves a detailed analysis of various metrics including solution capability and cost-effectiveness. The study proposes a Fast-TRACK model emphasizing strategic vision, comprehensive planning, and continuous improvement to navigate technology adoption and retention challenges effectively. Practical implications suggest that companies should adopt a holistic approach centered on strategic alignment and robust change management, with SAP urged to demonstrate the strategic value of their solutions and engage customer stakeholders early in the adoption phase to ensure technology implementations meet long-term goals and achieve higher satisfaction and retention rates.

Conclusion

This study explores technology adoption and contract retention using semi-structured interviews and NVivo's Lexical analysis, highlighting the importance of aligning technology with business needs, effective change management, cost considerations, and strategic implementation. Key themes include the influence of perception, organizational alignment, cost, complexity, ease of use, effective change management, and vendor support on technology adoption and retention. The research, set within a leading software corporation, provides valuable insights and validates findings with additional data. It introduces the Fast-Track model, emphasizing strategic considerations and practical implementations for leveraging technology for competitive advantage. The study also underscores the importance of understanding external barriers and enablers, such as cost, industrial norms, competition, and vendor support. The contributions of the research include extending the Balanced Scorecard approach to incorporate digital transformation, offering managerial recommendations, and providing a comprehensive framework (Fast-Track model) for navigating technology adoption and retention. Managerial recommendations include adopting a structured approach to technology integration, fostering a culture of continuous learning, and investing in robust knowledge management systems. Future research topics suggested include the impact of customer confusion on technology adoption, testing the FUTARE model across different regions and company sizes, and its effectiveness on upselling or expanding service contracts. The study provides valuable insights and practical recommendations for organizations aiming to enhance their technology adoption strategies and retain contracts effectively.

The Robust Technology Adoption and Contract Retention Model (Fast-Track) highlights the need for strategic alignment between technology vendors and users within organizational, personal, and external domains for successful technology adoption and retention. Vendors should deeply understand client structures to tailor technologies that integrate seamlessly into client workflows, enhancing operational effectiveness while maintaining compliance with industry regulations. Prospective clients must ensure these technologies align with strategic goals and existing systems. Proper training for users and insightful adjustment to external factors such as competitive trends are paramount. Broadly, managing the dynamics at the vision to planning phase involving pre-sales to sales within both organizational users and technology vendors is critical. This structured approach will help navigate through barriers and enablers, setting a solid base for adopting new technologies and retaining contracts effectively.

 

If you'd like to explore further, my full research article with reproach is available here. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you wish to discuss the research findings.

Find my Linked Profile: https://www.linkedin.com/in/mi4po/

entry.title: Small but Great: Introducing Micro-Integrations for Advanced Event Mesh
entry.content:
The Mesh

SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh is more than just a broker ‚Äì it allows you to build a mesh of event brokers. Once on the mesh, events can flow through your enterprise providing a veritable nervous system that allows your company to even become better in what you do ‚Äì faster, more reactive, more scalable, more flexible, more open to your employee‚Äôs ideas and your customer‚Äôs and supplier‚Äôs technology.

Once on the Mesh

Now we have added to this ‚Äúmore than just a broker‚Äù ‚Äì SAP has just, on November 28th, released Micro-Integrations for SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh.

Let‚Äôs go back to the second sentence you have read above: once on the mesh, events can flow ‚Ä¶ Often the question was: how do I get the events on the mesh from my event source, or off the mesh to the event consumer? Micro-Integrations facilitate exactly this on-ramp to and off-ramp from the mesh.

Micro-Integrations

Micro-Integrations are small, lightweight, event-driven integration modules that connect enterprise technologies (legacy and SaaS applications, messaging services, data bases, files, AI agents, etc.) to an event-driven distribution layer, so they can exchange information in real-time.  Advanced Event Mesh Micro-Integrations serve as on-ramp and off-ramp to the mesh ‚Äì a network of meshed SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh brokers. 

Scope of Micro-Integrations

Micro-Integrations focus on specific, narrowly defined tasks or processes.  They are easier to design and change without impact to any other systems because the effect and risk of the change is localized.  The reason for this is that a Micro-Integration (MI) does not connect two applications with each other. A MI connects a given application as an event source to the mesh (On-Ramp) or event target from the mesh (off-ramp). Resulting from the event-driven approach and the power of Advanced Event Mesh, high throughput data streams flow faster.

Micro-Integrations include a source or target connector which establishes a data flow between an event distribution layer like an event mesh and some source/target system.

Micro-Integrations are available in the Cloud Console and allow you to manage and observe the state of an integration between your external system and an event broker service or event mesh. 

Benefits of Micro-Integrations

Micro-Integrations are highly beneficial for modernizing integrations with event-driven architecture and the benefits they offer include

  1. Greater Agility: easy to change how applications and services interact with one another
  2. Faster data distribution: better real-time performance than traditional integration patterns and fast streaming capabilities
  3. Better/Easy Scalability: improved scalability by use of pub/sub to distribute events and by option to add additional Micro-Integrations to specific task
  4. More Flexibility: different technologies can be used at source or target sides depending on best fit technology, commercials or technology evolution

Available Micro-Integrations

A number of Micro-Integrations are currently available for use with SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh and SAP adds new Micro-Integrations to this list frequently. The currently available Micro-Integrations include:

  • Azure Service Bus
  • Amazon SNS
  • Amazon SQS
  • MQTT
  • Network files services SFTP
  • IBM MQ
  • Google Pub/Sub
  • AWS SQS
  • Snowflake
  • Oracle Advanced Queuing
  • Salesforce 

More Micro-Integrations are planned to be made available.

Pre-Requisites and Commercials

Micro-Integrations require an SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh broker ‚Äì a certain number of Micro-Integrations is included with the bigger AEM brokers. For the current commercial offering an Advanced Event Mesh broker of the 1K tier or higher is required (version 10.2.1 or later). The 1k broker for example includes a usage right for 2 Micro-Integrations which you can choose from the list of Micro-Integrations available for AEM.

Micro-Integrations are supported on Public Regions, Dedicated Regions, and Customer-Controlled Regions.

Understanding Micro-Integrations

A Micro-Integration defines how data should move between an external system and Advanced Event Mesh. A Micro-Integration includes a source or target connector which establishes data flow between an event distribution layer (i.e. Advanced Event Mesh) and some other source or target system.

So, there are two types of Micro-Integrations:

  • With a target Micro-Integration, data streams from an SAP event broker service to the external system.
  • With a source Micro-Integration, data streams from the external system to an SAP event broker service.

You decide at creation time whether to create a source or target Micro-Integration. A Micro-Integration contains up to five Flows that share the same connection information but differ in their endpoints. This allows you to group similar integrations and manage them as a single deployment, simplifying configuration and reducing operational costs.

The way forward

Customers with supported brokers can as of today use start using Micro-Integrations ‚Äì supported again means a 1K broker or higher.

With the feature introduced, we intend to provide it in future via additional channels as well.

This is work in progress, so stay tuned for updates here.

Getting Started

Find additional information on Micro-Integrations for Advanced Event Mesh here:

Documentation

entry.title: Roadblocks to AI Adoption
entry.content:
Introduction

In an era defined by rapid technological advancement, businesses face both significant challenges and valuable opportunities as they pursue digital transformation and integrate AI-driven solutions. As organisations work to maintain a competitive edge, AI‚Äôs impact on business strategy, customer experience, and operational efficiency has become increasingly pivotal.

As part of my recent doctoral studies in Digitalisation, specialising in Technology Adoption and AI Integration at IAE Nice, Graduate School of Management, Universit√© C√¥te d‚ÄôAzur, I explored this evolving landscape in depth through research focused on SAP customers. I am Happy to share the key findings through a series of insightful and practical articles, each offering guidance for both SAP customer leadership and SAP executives navigating the complexities of AI adoption and technology transformation.

 

  1. Maximising AI Potential: A Blueprint for Business Success
  2. Roadblocks to AI Adoption (THIS ARTICLE)
  3. Is SAP Business Data Cloud the Answer to Your AI Ambitions?

Photo by adventtron Unsplash

With advancements in technology continually reshaping the business landscape, artificial intelligence (AI) stands out as a transformative force across industries. However, despite its potential, many organizations stumble on the road to successful AI adoption. Understanding these barriers is critical for any business hoping to leverage AI effectively.

Organizational Readiness and Resistance to Change

One of the foremost challenges in AI adoption is the readiness of an organization to integrate new technology. According to recent studies conducted by the author within SAP, involving 29 SAP customers and their SAP counterparts, many businesses lack the necessary infrastructure, skilled personnel, and strategic vision to implement AI successfully. Additionally, the cultural resistance within organizations can be a significant hurdle. Employees often fear job displacement due to automation or feel overwhelmed by the pace of technological change, thereby resisting new implementations. A customer from the Oil & Gas industry in EMEA South as part of an interview with the author stated that " The transformation is happening in three areas: people, processes, and technology. One significant challenge is that people often resist change, which is something we frequently notice when adopting new technologies. Sometimes, these technology is introduced without a proper change management. As a result, the leadership faces langes in later stages to manage the change and convince the end users to accept the AI automation and overcome their initial hesitations and fear."

Cost and Complexity Considerations

The cost involved in deploying AI solutions is another significant barrier. Setting up AI systems requires substantial initial investment in technology and training, which can be a deterrent especially for SME enterprises. Moreover, the complexity of AI technology itself poses a challenge. Companies must ensure they have the expertise to not just implement but also maintain and scale AI solutions, which often necessitates costly ongoing training and development. A customer in the Chemicals sector from EMEA South reports to the author of this article that "Yeah, it's an easy question because in the end if there's a SAP competitor upcoming next year with a cheaper alternative, then we will think about going for the SAP‚Äôs competition." According to a CSM from EMEA South team share his experience saying with the author "A customer that I managed a couple of years ago has moved away from us and they moved to a SAP‚Äôs competitor due to the cost of our solutions"

Data Privacy and Security Concerns

Data is the lifeblood of AI. However, the increasing stringency of data protection regulations such as GDPR in Europe presents a compliance maze for companies to navigate. Ensuring data privacy and securing AI interactions becomes a critical concern that companies must address, adding another layer of complexity to AI adoption. A Higher Education industry customer based in EMEA North shares that with the author "Data Privacy and security is absolutely a concern even today, thought it really depends very much on the industry."

Lack of Clear ROI

The uncertainty about the return on investment (ROI) from AI projects also serves as a barrier. AI initiatives can be experimental in nature, making it difficult to predict outcomes precisely. This uncertainty can make stakeholders hesitant to commit the required resources, slowing down or even halting AI adoption processes.

Vendor Selection and Integration Challenges

Choosing the right technology provider and ensuring the integration of AI with existing systems is another challenge for our customers. Businesses often struggle with choosing between SAP and multiple other options, each promising superior capabilities. Making the wrong choice can lead to integration issues, wasted resources, and failed projects. MEA North‚Äôs Oil & Gas industry customer expresses in an interview with the Author that "It also plays a very important role in the industry where I'm working right now, where we have to leaverage technology and AI to lead the market and to deliver the requirement of our demanding customers worldwide."

Moving Forward: Recommendations for Overcoming AI Adoption Barriers

1.        At SAP, we understand the importance of cultivating a culture receptive to innovation. We must work with your business to develop comprehensive change management strategies. Our support will help alleviate resistance and ensure a smooth integration of AI into our customer‚Äôs existing processes, fostering continuous learning and adaptability.

2.        At SAP, we recommend allocating resources for essential infrastructure upgrades such as RISE with SAP. Our team should assist in building AI competency through employee training programs which our leadership is already heavely investing. Additionally, we can help establish partnerships with universities and tech institutes, ensuring a steady flow of skilled talent to support your AI initiatives.

3.        At SAP, we prioritise data security. Its necessary for us to help strengthen our customer‚Äôs cybersecurity measures and ensure compliance with data protection laws. By safeguarding customer operations, we will build trust among stakeholders, thereby smoothing the path for successful AI integration.

4.        To demonstrate the value of AI projects, we ought to work with customers to establish clear metrics for evaluating their performance. This will help secure ongoing support from stakeholders by showcasing tangible results and a positive return on investment.

5.        We believe in transparency and performance. By implementing a robust assessment process from our solutions, including pilot projects and performance benchmarks, we will ensure that our collaboration best matches our customers's needs. Our commitment is to be our customer‚Äôs trusted  partner, guiding customers through successful AI adoption and implementation is the key.

Conclusion

In summary, while artificial intelligence promises transformative benefits for businesses, the journey to successful AI adoption is fraught with challenges. These roadblocks range from organisational readiness and resistance to change, cost and complexity considerations, data privacy and security concerns, uncertainty about ROI, to vendor selection and integration issues. To overcome these hurdles, businesses must approach AI adoption strategically and holistically.

At SAP, we understand these challenges and are committed to helping our customers navigate them effectively. In the light of above information, I do recommend to focusing on cultural receptivity, infrastructure upgrades, data security, clear ROI metrics, and transparent in our sales strategies, and strive to be a trusted partner in our customers' AI adoption journey. Through comprehensive change management, skill development, robust cybersecurity measures, and performance benchmarking, SAP can aim to smooth the path to successful AI integration. By addressing these barriers head-on and fostering a collaborative approach, businesses can unlock the full potential of AI and drive meaningful growth and innovation.

entry.title: Job to check STOs w/o outbound deliveries and create it
entry.content:
Hello, experts!

We are having an issue where some outbound deliveries are not being created automatically or are being created with a significant delay. We have an active configuration in SPRO that is supposed to generate them automatically (MM > Purchasing > PO > Set up STO > Activate Automatic Delivery Creation and CRM Billing). We're still investigating the issue, but I'm considering a workaround process.

The idea is to create a job that checks every 5 or 10 minutes which STOs don't have an OB and generates it. This way, if the creation takes longer than expected (it is supposed to be created when the STO is posted), the job will generate it. I'm looking for a program that will check if STO already has an OB. If no delivery is found, it will create it automatically. The main objective is to prevent users from feeling the impact of this delay. Which program can I use?

Thanks!

Victor

entry.title: Re: Datasphere SQL: expected_unsigned_integer error on ti...
entry.content: Yes, the problem is that when the SQL view is defined, the output column has a fixed field length (let's say 5000). Then if I try to use that as a derive-value view in an Analytic Model, for a field, that is say, 10 characters, the result from the view will be string(5000) and the target field will be string(10). This will raise an error that the format doesn't match.
